talk.start.para: y. - On the 4th May, 1945, the honorable member for Moreton (Mr. Francis) asked the following question : -

quote.para: Will the Minister representing the Acting Minister for the Army or the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Customs inform the House whether it is the policy of the Government to exclude members of the Australian Imperial Force discharged as medically unfit on a 100 per cent pension from obtaining a personal tobacco ration? If not, can the Minister explain why ex-QX27634, Mervyn Taylor, discharged in November, 1943, was advised that, as the tobacco ration scheme for discharged personnel did not come into operation until the 1st January, 1944, he was not entitled to a ration ? Will the Minister have the case investigated, and, after consultation with the appropriate Minister, make a full statement to the House?

question.para: The Minister for Trade and Customs has now supplied the following answer : -

quote.para: The position regarding this matter is that a scheme covering privileged supplies of tobacco and cigarettes for discharged servicemen and servicewomen has been in operation during the past twelve months. Under this scheme all persons discharged from the Fighting Services on and after the 1st January, 1944, are issued with permits authorizing a monthly supply of tobacco or cigarettes, provided application is made within six months of the date of discharge. To date, more than 75,000 dischargees are drawing privileged supplies under the scheme in question.

question.para: Special provision has not been made for servicemen discharged prior to the 1st January, 1944, for the reason that each of such men would have had the opportunity of establishing himself as a customer of one or more tobacco retailers.

It is realized that anomalies in this connexion will arise, and authority has been given for the extension of the privilege in cases of undue hardship, details of which are required to be submitted to the chairman, Tobacco Distribution Committee, in the capital city of the State concerned.
The case of the discharged soldier specifically mentioned appears to he one for special consideration and, if the honorable member will furnish me with the details I shall look into the matter.

talk.start.para: - The honorable member for Martin (Mr. Daly), speaking on the motion for the adjournment of the House of the 3rd May, 1945, read the following letter from a serviceman: -

quote.para: Just recently we have heard of the Minister for Trade and Customs announcing that a 5 per cent issue of tobacco above the normal monthly rate was now available to civilians, while at the same time the service issue was cut 33 per cent. Whilst we do not argue with the issue to the civilian population, it is definitely a cut out of all proportion which the serviceman has had to suffer. In other words, this over-issue to the services has been granted. But this is not so, as the previous scale of 3 ounces a week was just sufficient for the average normal smoker in the Army, for it must be understood that things being equal, the serviceman, through the nature of his surroundings and conditions, is inclined to value such comforts as he can receive and look for them more than a civilian. So on behalf of the men of my unit, I am writing in the hope that through the organization of the Returned Sailors, Soldiers and Airmen's Imperial League of Australia something may be done to correct this anomaly, as the present issue of the tobacco is very far from satisfactory, more so as quite a lot of firms issue a ration of tobacco to their employees, who may also get it outside their firm, a condition of which the soldier has not the chance to avail himself.

answer.para: The honorable member asked that the points raised in the letter should be inquired into by the Minister for Trade and
Customs (Senator Keane) and the Acting Minister for the Army (Senator Fraser).
The Minister for Trade and Customs has now furnished the following explanation : -

quote.para: The position regarding this matter is that until 1st April, 1945, all members of the fighting services (both male and female) whether within Australia, in New Guinea or Pacific areas, have been supplied on the basis of 3 ounces tobacco or 105 cigarettes a week, less deduction for non-smokers - 10 per cent, males and 25 per cent, females.

During the period of tobacco rationing, supplies to the civilian community have been subject to degrees of rationing varying from 20 per cent, to 35 per cent., e.g.: December, 1944, 25 per cent.; January, 1945, 30 per cent.; February, 1945, 35 per cent.; March, 1945, 35 per cent. The drastic reduction in civilian supplies during recent months has been brought about by a combination of circumstances, viz. -

item.label: (a)
item.para: greatly reduced factory output occasioned by recurring man-power difficulties ;

item.label: (b)
item.para: serious decline in manufacturers' normal reserve stocks;

item.label: (c)
item.para: additional heavy commitments to provide for movements of troops to new Pacificbases.

quote.para: The 5 per cent increase to civilians as from 1st April, 1945, referred to by Mr. Daly represented the restoration of civilian supplies to the same degree of rationing applicable in January, 1945.

As from 1st April, 1945, the basic ration for services personnel located south of the Tropic of Capricorn was reduced to 2 ounces tobacco or 70 cigarettes a week. Such reduced ration to personnel, whether in static camps, training groups, base establishments or records offices, compares very favorably with the average weekly ration available for civilian smokers whether serviced through ordinary retail channels or factory canteens.
For the three months ended March, 1945, the average ration available to such civilian consumers was less than 1½ ounces tobacco or 52 cigarettes a week.

The whole question of tobacco and cigarette supplies for the fighting services in New Guinea and Pacific areas and within Australia, is at present being closely examined with a view to necessary readjustments, but in this connexion I am strongly of the opinion that a larger basic ration should continue to he made available to fighting personnel in New Guinea and Pacific areas as compared with servicemen and servicewomen in non-operational areas.

talk.start.para: asked the Act ing Attorney-General, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that a number of German nationals and German naturalized Australians have been released from internment recently by ministerial direction in the face of adverse recommendations by an advisory tribunal presided over by a New South Wales Supreme Court judge?

talk.start.para: - The answers . to the honorable member's questions areas follows : -

item.para: It is correct that a number of German nationals and naturalized British subjects of German origin have been released from internment. These releases have been granted after the most careful investigation by and on the recommendation of the Director-General of Security in each individual case and subject to the imposition of suitable restrictions.

Beinssen is a British subject, born in Australia, but of German origin. He fought for Germany in the first world war, but the Director-General of Security reports that it would be incorrect to, describe him as an active Nazi. The fact is that he, together with his wife and three children, was interned early in 1940; In September, 1944, his case was reviewed and it was decided to release him together with his family under restriction to a property in the Orange district which he could only leave by permission of Security Service. There is no legal prohibition to a British subject acquiring property.

Applications for naturalization have been received from aliens released from internment. Before any application ia considered, the Minister must be satisfied that the applicant ia a fit and proper person to become naturalized. No person will be naturalized against whom there is any security objection. Bach case will be handled on its merits.
